body:
githubbot:

GitHub user rfer opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54

CURATOR-166: Allow ZKPaths to build paths with an arbitrary number of children

ZKPaths currently only accepts one parent and one child nodes.
This changes makePaths to have a varargs parameter so it can accept more than one child.

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/rfer/curator CURATOR-166

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #54

commit 01a23e9c043277ab80d9f78b8c58b7aab06c902b
Author: Ricardo Ferreira
Date: 2014-11-14T23:48:31Z

CURATOR-166: Allow ZKPaths to build paths with an arbitrary number of children.
LGTM.

githubbot:

Github user madrob commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#issuecomment-63321963

LGTM.
Would it make sense to drop the "parent" argument and just have makePath(Sting...)? I can't tell if the logic would collapse nicely or if it would get really messy just by looking at it.

githubbot:

Github user madrob commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#issuecomment-63323871

Would it make sense to drop the "parent" argument and just have makePath(Sting...)? I can't tell if the logic would collapse nicely or if it would get really messy just by looking at it.
The reason I didn't do that is because that would break the API, whereas it won't with this change.

githubbot:

Github user rfer commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#issuecomment-63325006

The reason I didn't do that is because that would break the API, whereas it won't with this change.

Would it? Calls of the form makePath(String, String) would get turned into a two-argument array for makePath(String...) and everything would still be compatible. I might be missing some nuance of varargs, though.

githubbot:

Github user madrob commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#issuecomment-63327315

Would it? Calls of the form makePath(String, String) would get turned into a two-argument array for makePath(String...) and everything would still be compatible. I might be missing some nuance of varargs, though.
You're right, my mistake. In that case the only disadvantage I see is that it makes it possible to call makePath with no arguments. Not exactly sure if that would be a problem though.

githubbot:

Github user rfer commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#issuecomment-63329022

You're right, my mistake. In that case the only disadvantage I see is that it makes it possible to call makePath with no arguments. No exactly sure if that would be a problem though.
We already consider it valid to call with an empty parent and child, so it would not be too surprising to have makePath() behave the same as makePath(null) and makePath(null, null) by returning "/".

githubbot:

Github user madrob commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#issuecomment-63331319

We already consider it valid to call with an empty parent and child, so it would not be too surprising to have makePath() behave the same as makePath(null) and makePath(null, null) by returning "/".

githubbot:

Github user dragonsinth commented on a diff in the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#discussion_r20450851

— Diff: curator-client/src/main/java/org/apache/curator/utils/ZKPaths.java —
@@ -276,26 +282,26 @@ public static void deleteChildren(ZooKeeper zookeeper, String path, boolean dele
Collections.sort(sortedList);
return sortedList;
}
-
+
/**

  • * Given a parent path and a child node, create a combined full path
    + * Given a parent path and a list of children nodes, create a combined full path
    *
  • @param parent the parent
  • * @param child the child
    + * @param children the children
  • @return full path
    */
  • public static String makePath(String parent, String child)
    + public static String makePath(String parent, String... children)
      • End diff –

I would probably make 2 overloads here:

`makePath(String, String)`
`makePath(String, String, String...)`

1) Preserve binary compatibility; changing the last to a vararg breaks binary compat if you don't recompile client code.
2) Not introduce the extra array allocation for the most common 2-arg case.

-

/**

  • * Given a parent path and a child node, create a combined full path

githubbot:

Github user rfer commented on a diff in the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/54#discussion_r20473248

— Diff: curator-client/src/main/java/org/apache/curator/utils/ZKPaths.java —
@@ -276,26 +282,26 @@ public static void deleteChildren(ZooKeeper zookeeper, String path, boolean dele
Collections.sort(sortedList);
return sortedList;
}
-
+
/**

  • * Given a parent path and a child node, create a combined full path
    + * Given a parent path and a list of children nodes, create a combined full path
    *
  • @param parent the parent
  • * @param child the child
    + * @param children the children
  • @return full path
    */
  • public static String makePath(String parent, String child)
    + public static String makePath(String parent, String... children)
      • End diff –

Yes, that makes sense. I updated the change. In order to avoid code duplication and multiple StringBuilder instantiations, I've added a new auxiliary method that mutates a StringBuilder passd as an argument.

dragonsinth:

Thanks for the report! Do you have / are you working on a fix already? If not I can take a look.

mcnallyc:

Unfortunately I do not have a fix. Thanks in advance for your help.

mdrob:

I just tried running this as a JUnit test against the latest trunk, and did not see the same behaviour.

I am running on a Ubuntu 14.04 system, with Java 7. I set the heap size to 32m because Maven and Surefire needed a bit more room to start up, and monitoring via JVisualVM I saw cyclical heap growth and then GC returning the heap size to the normal level.

Looks like you've got your work cut out for you, Scott Blum. Let me know if I can help with testing in any way.

cammckenzie:

I can reproduce the problem on a WIndows 7 box running Java 1.6

cammckenzie:

Looking briefly at the code, it would seem that this is probably just because the NamespaceWatcherMap is holding references to all of the Watcher references that are created by the NodeCache (which being an inner class will hold a reference to the NodeCache itself). This means that a bunch of objects are not going to be cleaned up the GC. I'm not sure what the solution is though. Maybe the NodeCache needs to keep track of all of its Watcher references and ask for them to be removed from the NamespaceWatcherMap when it closes. The NamespaceWatcherMap is hidden under a few layers of abstraction though, so it's not going to be very clean!

randgalt:

We can try adding a call to clearWatcherReferences()

cammckenzie:

Yep, good call. Unfortunately this only takes an org.apache.zookeeper.Watcher reference and the one used by NodeCache uses a org.curator.framework.api.CuratorWatcher. I will hack it for now and see if it fixes the leak.

cammckenzie:

This definitely reduces the size of the memory leak. The JVM was running out of memory with a 10M heap after 10000 iterations before. After making a quick hack fix to clear watch references on close of the NodeCache it now runs out of memory after 27000 iterations. So, there's something else going on too. I haven't profiled it yet.

mcnallyc:

Wow, thanks for jumping right on this!

I didn't mention this in the original post because I hadn't done all my homework so to speak, but I also think I've seen a similar leak w/ NodeCache/ConnectionStateListener/ConnectionStateManager. I saw this with the older client (1.3.3) but haven't had the time to write a test against this one as well...

I'll attach another screenshot from yourkit java profiler that shows this. I have no idea if this is fixed in 2.6.0.

If you'd rather I can open a separate bug report for this once I have a test that illustrates it. It might not be for a bit though as I'm busy with other things.

randgalt:

Have a look at PathChildrenCache.close()

cammckenzie:

Jordan Zimmerman I tried adding all of the other shenanigans from the PathChildrenCache.close() to the NodeCache(), but no difference. Still dies of an exception after 27000 or so open / close iterations. I'm wondering if it could just be that the ZK client is keeping track of all of the watches? Because in this test, none of the watches ever fire, so they may just be continually stacking up.

Craig McNally, don't worry about another JIRA for now. I think that these are all probably related.

randgalt:

There is no way to clear a watch. So, they would collect inside of ZooKeeper.

cammckenzie:

Jordan Zimmerman that would explain the ZK server's memory usage increasing, but does the client also keep track of the watches?

randgalt:

Yes, the client holds on to them. It has to as they are functors.

cammckenzie:

Yep, had a brief look through the ZK client code, it would seem that data, exists and child watches are stored in a series of HashMap's in the client. So, this test is possibly a bit bogus, because there's no chance of any of the watches firing which would result in them being removed (because the NodeCache has been closed and won't reregister the watch). I'll make sure that if the watches fire that they do get cleared.

This may be something that needs to be fixed as part of the Curator support for ZK 3.5.

cammckenzie:

Ok, so if I modify the test slightly to make sure that the watches fire, then they get cleared as expected. This issue is not specific to NodeCache (there are already 2 other memory related issues CURATOR-14 and CURATOR-105). The issue could be minimized (which I believe CURATOR-14 was trying to do) by caching identical watches in Curator), but for the pathological case (like this test exhibits) where a new node is used for each watch, a watcher cache would not work.

I think that we need to fix this with ZK 3.5 where we can actually remove watches.

dragonsinth:

Still seems like we could clean up unreferenced client side watches, to solve the case of starting and stopping caches that look at the same paths. For that case, the server will limit you to 1 watch per client per node anyway.

cammckenzie:

Scott Blum good point. We should still fix the close() method to call into clearWatcherReferences() to clean up the Curator side of things. This will require a small amount of shenanigans though, as the watcher used by NodeCache is a CuratorWatcher and the clearWatcherReferences() call exposed by the CuratorFramework interface currently only supports ZK Watcher objects (which share no base class with CuratorWatcher).

So, do we expose a second clearWatcherReferences() method? Or does anyone have another suggestion?

randgalt:

I would just change the watcher to a normal Watcher.

cammckenzie:

Ok. Will sort out a fix

githubbot:

GitHub user cammckenzie opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/55

CURATOR-167 - Partial fix to clean up Curator managed watch objects

CURATOR-167 - Partial fix to clean up Curator managed watch objects whenthe cache closes. A full fix requires the ability to cancel watches in ZK which is not available until ZK 3.5

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/apache/curator CURATOR-167

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/55.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #55

commit 44c3891e3e1633e456c530165513fff50a52a8b4
Author: Cameron McKenzie
Date: 2014-11-19T03:23:24Z

CURATOR-167 - Partial fix to clean up Curator managed watch objects when
the cache closes. A full fix requires the ability to cancel watches in
ZK which is not available until ZK 3.5

No unit tests yet, couldn't think of a good way of testing without having a test that ran for a long time. I guess an option is to look at the size of the watcher cache, but it's not super accessible (I guess you could get at it with some reflection shenanigans).

BTW: do PathChildrenCache and TreeCache have similar issues?

Cameron McKenzie  on dev@curator.apache.org replies:
I don't think path children cache does, I think that tree cache may, will
have a look tomorrow

mcnallyc:

Scott Blum, looks like a similar problem was already identified and fixed for PathChildrenCache. See CURATOR-105.

It looks like TreeCache might be fine here.

```
TreeCache.close() -> TreeCacheNode.wasDeleted() [recursively] -> client.clearWatcherReferences(this)
```

```
TreeCache.close() -> TreeCacheNode.wasDeleted() [recursively] -> client.clearWatcherReferences(this)
```
Yep, I think you're right, should be ok.

right now, fromConfig() is required. It should be optional. i.e. I should be able to write:

```
client.reconfig().leaving("").joining("").forEnsemble();
```

```

  • @param fromConfig
  • version of the current configuration (optional - causes reconfiguration to throw an exception if configuration is no longer current)
    ```

Also, in the ZK code,

```
long configId = reconfigRequest.getCurConfigId();

if (configId != -1 && configId!=lzks.self.getLastSeenQuorumVerifier().getVersion()){
```

osmanscam:

getting the same issue with curator version 4.6 as well, so highlighting that none of the fixes from 4.6 to 4.7 is causing that, here is the full stack trace

[CuratorFramework-0-EventThread] ERROR o.a.c.f.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl - Background exception was not retry-able or retry gave up
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Path must start with / character
at org.apache.curator.utils.PathUtils.validatePath(PathUtils.java:53)
at org.apache.curator.utils.ZKPaths.getNodeFromPath(ZKPaths.java:56)
at org.apache.curator.framework.recipes.leader.LeaderLatch.checkLeadership(LeaderLatch.java:523)
at org.apache.curator.framework.recipes.leader.LeaderLatch.access$700(LeaderLatch.java:62)
at org.apache.curator.framework.recipes.leader.LeaderLatch$7.processResult(LeaderLatch.java:581)
at org.apache.curator.framework.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl.sendToBackgroundCallback(CuratorFrameworkImpl.java:715)
at org.apache.curator.framework.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl.processBackgroundOperation(CuratorFrameworkImpl.java:502)
at org.apache.curator.framework.imps.GetChildrenBuilderImpl$2.processResult(GetChildrenBuilderImpl.java:166)
at org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn$EventThread.processEvent(ClientCnxn.java:590)
at org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn$EventThread.run(ClientCnxn.java:498)

(as it is happening quite seldom there is no testcase to reproduce this)

osmanscam:

Hi zhaogang;

Could you reproduce this issue with an unit test? Do you know exactly in which use case this is happening?

Regards.

mcnallyc:

Just curious if there's been any progress on this...

cammckenzie:

I'm pretty sure I've seen this occur once before as well in a test environment, but was never able to reproduce it. I don't suppose you happen to have any idea under what circumstances it may be occurring?

kylar:

Sadly, no. I can see in the traces the process by which it gets into that state, but I have no clue how to make it happen. It's pretty rare too, of all our instances, I've only had it happen twice.

cammckenzie:

I've had a bit of a look through the code and I think that your theory on what's happening is correct. For whatever reason the ZK connection cannot finish sending / receiving the packet, which in turn means that the checkTimeouts() method gets blocked indefinitely. So, I'm not exactly sure if this is a problem with Curator or a problem with ZK.

I would presume that ZK doesn't just read indefinitely waiting for a response for the packet that it sent, and there shouldn't be any interaction between the Curator synchronization and the ZK synchronization, so I'm really not sure.

kylar:

Happened again last night. Same stack trace in the CuratorFramework, but different holdups in the other threads. I didn't get an actual jstack, this was culled from an hprof that happened when we hit an OutOfMemory - we were accepting requests in the front end and backing up behind ZK. Once we had accumulated too much, we OOM'd.

SECOND ONE
CuratorFramework-0 tid=21 [WAITING] [DAEMON]
java.lang.Object.wait(long) Object.java
java.lang.Object.wait() Object.java:503
org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn.submitRequest(RequestHeader, Record, Record, ZooKeeper$WatchRegistration) ClientCnxn.java:1309
org.apache.zookeeper.ClientCnxn.close() ClientCnxn.java:1281
org.apache.zookeeper.ZooKeeper.close() ZooKeeper.java:677
org.apache.curator.HandleHolder.internalClose() HandleHolder.java:139
org.apache.curator.HandleHolder.closeAndReset() HandleHolder.java:77
org.apache.curator.ConnectionState.reset() ConnectionState.java:218
org.apache.curator.ConnectionState.checkTimeouts() ConnectionState.java:194
org.apache.curator.ConnectionState.getZooKeeper() ConnectionState.java:88
org.apache.curator.CuratorZookeeperClient.getZooKeeper() CuratorZookeeperClient.java:115
org.apache.curator.framework.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl.performBackgroundOperation(OperationAndData) CuratorFrameworkImpl.java:763
org.apache.curator.framework.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl.backgroundOperationsLoop() CuratorFrameworkImpl.java:749
org.apache.curator.framework.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl.access$300(CuratorFrameworkImpl) CuratorFrameworkImpl.java:56
org.apache.curator.framework.imps.CuratorFrameworkImpl$3.call() CuratorFrameworkImpl.java:244
java.util.concurrent.FutureTask$Sync.innerRun() FutureTask.java:334
java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run() FutureTask.java:166
java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor.runWorker(ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker) ThreadPoolExecutor.java:1110
java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run() ThreadPoolExecutor.java:603
java.lang.Thread.run() Thread.java:722

ContainerStateSupervisor-1 tid=156 [BLOCKED] [DAEMON]

cammckenzie:

I think that we just ran into the same problem in production. Must be that time of year!

Not positive it's the same issue as I couldn't get a jstack due to incompatibilities with JRE / JDK installed on the box in question, but the symptoms are certainly similar. I will try and have more of a look into it tomorrow, I'm still not convinced that it's a Curator issue though.

cammckenzie:

Had a bit more of a look, and I don't think that this is the issue the we encountered, as it seems that this can only happen when there's connection loss to ZK and we don't seem to be experiencing this.

I did step through the process with a debugger though and had a look at the ZK code, and I'm not quite sure how this situation can arise. The only way it seems possible is if the packet never finishes, but the timeout and connection loss handling seems to handle these cases. The second curator thread is being blocked because the checkTimeouts() method is synchronized, but the root of it is that the packet.finished state is not being reached for some reason. I don't know why this is though. It doesn't seem to me to be related to locking issues.

gopi:

I have submitted a pull request with the fix https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/58
Thanks,
Gopi

githubbot:

Github user gopikori commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/curator/pull/58#issuecomment-68265604

Not really. Because this was not a problem when the listener only considered the RECONNECTED state. Before the fix, although the listener was being registered earlier, the call to reRegisterServices() was prevented as the if condition ignored CONNECTED state. But now with the RECONNECTED state added to the if condition, this sequence change becomes necessary. Reverting any of the two changes causes multiple test cases failure. I hope I am clear.

Github user cammckenzie commented on a diff in the pull request:

— Diff: curator-framework/src/main/java/org/apache/curator/framework/imps/CuratorFrameworkImpl.java —
@@ -65,7 +69,7 @@
private final BlockingQueue> backgroundOperations;
private final NamespaceImpl namespace;
private final ConnectionStateManagerconnectionStateManager;

  • private final AtomicReference authInfo = new AtomicReference();
      • End diff –

@Randgalt, what was the rationale behind this being an AtomicReference originally? I can't see any thread safety issues as it's only set in the constructor.

cammckenzie:

You're correct about where the issue was introduced. So, this forces you to have a prefix for your sequential nodes.

The issue is that the ZKPaths.fixForNamespace() has no context as to whether the node being created is sequential or not.

Scott Blum, I believe that you added this fix. Any suggestions? We could just remove the validatePath() call from ZKPaths.fixForNamespace(), but it is arguably nice to have that validation there. Changing the fixForNamespace() stuff to be aware of the fact that the node being created is sequential is another option, but this will have a reasonably large impact as it's used in quite a number of places.

dragonsinth:

Yeah, I think I was trying to bring some sanity to String based path handling, it's been kind of a mess in the past, leading to situations where trying to combine path parts wound up with too many or not enough slashes in the right places

Is there any semantic different between "/foo" and "/foo/"?

cammckenzie:

In the path validation code in ZK itself (where I believe the Curator PathUtils class was borrowed from) "/foo/" is illegal. The exception is for sequential paths because they get a number appended to them which is what's happening in this case.

In the context of the fixForNamespace() method, there's no difference between "/foo/" and "/foo" because I believe that the call to makePaths() fixes the path even if it ends with a "/", though this would only happen if a namespace was active, so this is a bit inconsistent. I don't know if we could just make fixForNamespace() remove any trailing slash, it might break the sequential stuff.

dragonsinth:

I think what would be useful is a test case demonstrating the problem.

cammckenzie:

I reproduced the problem with a quick test (that I haven't committed), I will check it in on a CURATOR-179 branch when I get a minute.

cammckenzie:

I have added a simple test case to the CURATOR-179 branch that reproduces the problem. Removing the PathUtils.validatPath() from ZKPaths fixes the issue, but obviously we lose the advantages of this validation.
